information:
Economic challenges and trade policy are key sources of market uncertainty. Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have led to downward revisions of corporate earnings expectations. A Goldman Sachs model predicts that a 5% increase in tariffs could lead to a 1-2% decline in S&P 500 earnings per share. Sevens Report notes that even with reduced trade tensions, the base level of tariffs will remain much higher than in January, acting as a barrier to growth and a driver of inflation. Analysts at Barclays have expressed skepticism about whether there is enough momentum in U.S.-China trade discussions to avoid a U.S. recession.

In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

Several market-moving events are scheduled for late April and early May 2025. Major technology companies, including Microsoft, Meta, Apple, and Amazon, are set to release their first-quarter earnings reports. In total, over 180 S&P 500 companies are expected to report. Key economic data releases are also imminent, including the report on first-quarter GDP growth, the Personal Consumer Expenditures (PCE) inflation gauge for March, the ISM Manufacturing Index for April, and the April employment report. The Federal Reserve's next policy meeting is scheduled for May 7.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 1 month (until the final trading day of May 2025)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: S&P 500 ends May modestly higher than the April month-end close (small positive drift)
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Inflation data runs hot (PCE, ISM prices, wages), the Fed leans more hawkish on May 7, 10-year yields push higher, and one or two megacaps (e.g., Apple/Amazon) disappoint on earnings/guidance; valuation multiple compresses and the index finishes May below the April close
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Disinflation resumes or growth cools just enough to ease yields, the Fed sounds patient rather than hawkish, Big Tech earnings/guidance broadly reassure, volatility recedes; risk appetite and AI-led momentum lift the index to a higher month-end close than April
forecast.rationale: Base-rate view: The S&P 500 finishes a given month higher roughly 55–60% of the time; May specifically has been slightly positive on average. That status-quo tendency toward a small monthly gain anchors me slightly above 50%. Current setup: Per the assistant’s report, the index just staged a strong rebound into late April (weekly close 5,525.21, +4.6%). Valuations are elevated (P/E well above historical averages) and the VIX near ~25 signals above-normal event risk. The next month is dense with catalysts: mega-cap earnings (Apple/Amazon still ahead), key macro prints (Q1 GDP details, March PCE, April ISM, April payrolls), and the May 7 FOMC. How that flow resolves will likely dominate May’s direction. Why not higher: The hurdle may be elevated if April’s final close is near the late-April rebound level; with valuations rich and rates sensitive to inflation surprises, a modest negative shock could push May below April’s close. Elevated VIX and policy/earnings event risk argue against a confident bullish tilt. Why not lower: Earnings momentum from large tech has recently improved, and buy-the-dip behavior remains common in this regime. A ‘Goldilocks’ mix (cooling inflation without sharp growth deterioration) could easily deliver a small positive month, consistent with the base rate. What would move me up: Broadly positive Big Tech results/guidance; cooler PCE and wage data; a patient Fed tone; 10-year yields drifting lower; VIX subsiding toward the mid-teens and market breadth improving. What would move me down: Hot inflation or sticky services prices; a hawkish Fed that pushes back on 2025 cuts; downside surprises from Apple/Amazon or AI capex tempering; 10-year yields pressing materially higher; geopolitical risk flare-ups. Summary of provided info affecting the view: strong late-April rally to ~5,525, elevated valuations (P/E 19–28), VIX ~25, a packed early-May calendar (earnings from major tech, GDP, PCE, ISM, jobs) and the May 7 Fed meeting. Weighing the status-quo slight upward drift against elevated near-term risk, I lean modestly Yes but close to even.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the S&P 500 index go up in May 2025?

Question background:
NY Times: [What Is a Bear Market? Are We in One?](https://www.nytimes.com/article/bear-market-stocks-tariffs.html)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question will resolve as Yes if the closing value of the S&P 500 Index on the final trading day of May 2025 is higher than that of the final trading day of April 2025.

The "close" values shown on the [history page of Yahoo finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5EGSPC/history?p=%5EGSPC) will be used.


Your research assistant's report says:
Economic challenges and trade policy are key sources of market uncertainty. Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have led to downward revisions of corporate earnings expectations. A Goldman Sachs model predicts that a 5% increase in tariffs could lead to a 1-2% decline in S&P 500 earnings per share. Sevens Report notes that even with reduced trade tensions, the base level of tariffs will remain much higher than in January, acting as a barrier to growth and a driver of inflation. Analysts at Barclays have expressed skepticism about whether there is enough momentum in U.S.-China trade discussions to avoid a U.S. recession.

In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

Several market-moving events are scheduled for late April and early May 2025. Major technology companies, including Microsoft, Meta, Apple, and Amazon, are set to release their first-quarter earnings reports. In total, over 180 S&P 500 companies are expected to report. Key economic data releases are also imminent, including the report on first-quarter GDP growth, the Personal Consumer Expenditures (PCE) inflation gauge for March, the ISM Manufacturing Index for April, and the April employment report. The Federal Reserve's next policy meeting is scheduled for May 7.

Today is 2025-04-29.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
